bone.name: Patella
desc: The patella is articulated with the femur to protect the anterior articular surface of the knee joint, giving attachment to the patellar ligament and quadriceps tendon.
Patella fracture commonly occurs as a consequence of direct trauma to the knee, for example when hit against the dashboard in a vehicle collision.

bone.name: Medial femoral condyle
desc: The femoral condyles are covered by articular cartilage and function as a shock absorber for the knee.
The medial and lateral femoral condyles serve as important bony landmarks and palpation points as they are also the origin and insertion of ACL and PCL.

bone.name: Lateral femoral condyle
desc: The femoral condyles are covered by articular cartilage and function as a shock absorber for the knee.
The medial and lateral femoral condyles serve as important bony landmarks and palpation points as they are also the origin and insertion of ACL and PCL.

bone.name: Medial tibial condyle
desc: The medial and lateral tibial condyles combine to form the flat surface of the inner surface of the tibia. They are also closely related to ACL and PCL.

bone.name: Lateral tibial condyle
desc: The medial and lateral tibial condyles combine to form the flat surface of the inner surface of the tibia. They are also closely related to ACL and PCL.

bone.name: Tibial tuberosity
desc: The tibial tuberosity is a prominent bony landmark on the top of the tibia where the patellar tendon connects. It gives attachment to the patellar ligament.
Tibial tuberosity fractures are infrequent fractures, most common in adolescents during running and jumping movements.

ligament.name: Lateral collateral ligament
desc: The lateral collateral ligament is one of the major stabilizers of the knee joint and connects the femur to the fibula.
LCL is rarely injured alone and is often involved in lateral knee structural injuries with ACL and PCL.

ligament.name: Medial collateral ligament
desc: The medial collateral ligament connects the femur to the tibia.
MCL injury is usually caused by the knee being pushed inwards or twisting in activities such as skiing or swimming.

ligament.name: Patellar ligament
desc: The patellar ligament is the distal portion of the common tendon of the quadriceps femoris.The patellar tendon can be injured in a patellar tendon rupture. It can also be used as a tissue source in the repair of other ligaments such as ACL.

ligament.name: Anterior cruciate ligament
desc: The anterior cruciate ligament is one of the key ligaments that help stabilise the knee joint, and it connects the femur to the tibia. It is the most commonly injured ligament, especially during sports that involve sudden stops and changes in direction-such as basketball, soccer, tennis and volleyball.

ligament.name: Posterior cruciate ligament
desc: The posterior cruciate ligament connects the femur to the back of the tibia. It usually takes a powerful force to injure the posterior cruciate ligament, often caused by a direct blow to the front of the knee when itâ€™s bent, which extends it beyond the normal range of movement.

tendon.name: Quadriceps tendon
desc: The quadriceps tendon attaches the quadriceps to the top of the patella.
Quadriceps tendon rupture is a rare but serious injury and is related to age and multiple medical comorbidities.
